awd_titl_txt: The Effects of Sadness Versus Gratitude on Economic Decision Making and Addictive Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
The Appraisal-tendency framework (ATF) in emotion science describes how different emotions act to color the decisions an individual makes, even about things unrelated to the events or circumstances that induced the emotion. ATF correctly predicts, for example, that the experience of sadness makes people willing to pay more to acquire standard economic goods and services. The current research tests predictions of ATF regarding willingness to engage in pro-social behavior and decisions about consumption of addictive substances, for which emotions may have different, and potentially stronger, effects. The results of this research will contribute to our deeper understanding of the influence of affect on choice, as well as having potentially broad implications for the design of interventions to address substance abuse problems. 

The Principal Investigators will conduct five experiments that test whether experimentally inducing sadness or gratitude can alter simple altruism, cooperation, cigarette valuation, and sunk cost effects regarding cigarette consumption, and whether gratitude can counteract the effects of sadness. ATF predicts that sadness and gratitude will have diverging effects on pro-social behavior and addictive behavior, with gratitude increasing prosociality and reducing cigarette consumption and sadness doing the opposite.

por.por_cntn:
Most people recognize from their own experience and observations that emotion plays a vital role in human decision making.  Indeed, the epidemic of deaths attributable to addictive substances, including tobacco, highlights the need to better understand ways in which emotions drive substance craving and consumption.

Historically, however, the role that emotion plays in decision making has received little scientific attention.  Fortunately, scholarly papers examining the ways in which emotion influences decision making have more than doubled in recent years. One key insight emerging from this corpus is the value of linking specific emotions (as opposed to global positive/negative moods) to specific choice outcomes in order to increase predictive power and precision in decision. Yet at least one major gap remained at the time we began this project, despite its potential theoretical and practical import: Research had not yet systematically examined the influence of specific emotions on harmful health decisions, generally, and addictive substance-use decisions, specifically. Indeed, influential models of substance use behavior had concluded that undifferentiated negative affect predicted drug use and relapse among addicted substance users.  Whether such undifferentiated negative affect provided the best model had not been systematically tested.

The present project aimed to examine whether a valence-based model versus an emotion-specific model best predicts decision making for addictive substance use outcomes.  More specifically, the primary purpose of this research was to test the extent to which the Appraisal Tendency Framework (ATF), an emotion specific model, could help predict and explain substance use decisions, ultimately providing an evidentiary base from which to design interventions that reduce harmful health decisions.

The ATF explains how, when, and why emotions that are not directly related to a particular judgment or choice (known as incidental emotions) will affect that judgment or choice. The research tested hypotheses concerning the effects of incidental emotion on both economic decision making and addictive behavior (smoking). The ATF points to a clear empirical strategy: research should compare the effects of emotions that are highly differentiated in their appraisal themes for related judgments/choices/behaviors. In this case, because the appraisal themes of loss/emptiness and self-focus suggest implications for the valuing of goods, our studies contrasted emotions on opposite poles of the loss/emptiness dimension and the attentional focus dimension: sadness (loss/emptiness & self-focus) versus gratitude (gain/fullness and other-focus) in the context of additive substances and health-related decisions.

These experiments extended previous work addressing the role of emotions on appraisal tendencies, testing a set of hypotheses contrasting the effects of sadness, gratitude, and neutral emotion in the context of addiction. Importantly, studies also tested an intervention for reducing unwanted effects of sadness on economic behavior and on smoking intensity.

When examining how emotion affects economic decision making, we used in-person laboratory experiments, online experiments, and analysis of large existing datasets to examine the effects of emotion on decisions involving addictive behaviors, risk preferences, cheating behavior, financial patience, and corruption. Thus, this research bridged paradigms from behavioral economics with paradigms from public health to have maximal impact not only on theoretical development but also on practical application. The interdisciplinary team of researchers examined micro-level processes linking emotions with decisions and behavior to yield macro-level implications for human health and wellbeing.

In tests of alternative theories of emotion and decision making, we found that sadness, specifically, rather than negative mood, generally, increased addictive substance use. By contrast, we find that gratitude was associated with the opposite tendency.  In causal tests, gratitude decreased craving for cigarettes. Results provide not only theoretical implications but also policy implications for the design of antismoking public service announcements, which could unintentionally increase cigarette cravings among smokers if they trigger sadness.  Together, the present studies provide support for a more nuanced model regarding the effects of emotion on tobacco use, in particular, as well as on addictive behavior, in general.

Support for this project has resulted in 18 papers plus 1 under review and 1 in preparation.  As much as possible, we’ve aimed to publish in outlets that are widely distributed and often reviewed in major media outlets.  For example, papers from this project appear in such journals as Nature Human Behavior (two papers), the Proceedings of the National Academy of Science, and Affective Science.

Our team also disseminated knowledge about the effects of emotion on decision making and addictive behavior to broader audiences of students, the public, and policymakers. Implications were circulated to wider audiences through briefings for policymakers, scientific publications, and interviews with the press. When our final capstone paper comes out (currently in preparation), we will double our efforts on dissemination.  Across all aspects of this initiative, we hope the work demonstrates ways in which basic, theory-driven research can elucidate and, ultimately, improve human health and wellbeing.
